summary: Who is the true first Avenger?
body:
Who is the true first Avenger?

Captain America takes this title, typically, but what is the truth? Captain America was part of SHIELD first. However, Captain Marvel was the reason Fury started and named the project. Iron Man was the first Avenger who was actually recruited and joined the team. However, Thor is a god who has lived for thousands of years.

blog.title: Super-Hero-Confessions
blog.description:
Super-hero-confessions is a blog where you can submit your confessions/personal opinions about any of the super hero movies, comics, television shows, cartoons, etc.

The confessions that are posted are those that are submitted; not the opinions of the blog owners. All the confessions will be anonymous when posted. Feel free to submit photos along with your confession if you would like as well.

If you want us to see a post tag it with either #superheroconfessions or #superhero confessions

summary: The guy in the Superman tee is Superman. He lost his powers for a bit so he went with the ol' Conner Kent jeans-and-a-tshirt...
question: The guy in the Superman tee is Superman. He lost his powers for a bit so he went with the ol' Conner Kent jeans-and-a-tshirt look
answer:
Haha thank! You know, I vaguely remembered the power loss phase as one of the elements early on in the confusing multiverse Superman-overlap mashup nightmare they put us through since Flashpoint, but I missed entirely that he got mixed up in Dick’s shitty secret agent career!

XD Just. Fully mortal and doing the driving in a high-speed motorcycle chase of doom, huh.

Uncle Clark you are Too Good, and also…really not well drawn right there wow. I looked at his face and was like ‘should I know this person or is it a shanghaied mook of some sort?’ I suppose he had to made Dick look especially pretty by contrast.

DC, create models incorporating standardized cues to distinguish your iconic buff dark haired white dudes plzzzzzzzzzzzz. Give Superman brown eyes or something. Make their noses different. Assign either Batman or Superman a permanent cleft in his chin. Something.

Fan artist mass consensus tends to yield more readable character distinctions, guys. You can allow people a lot of artistic freedom and still maintain The Distinctive Features!

The downside, I suppose, is it would then become more difficult to make them evolve with the fashions of beauty; Captain Marvel (Shazam) sorta kept the same basic look for decades even as it drifted further and further from the consensus hot, and the chin has contributed to his reputation for goofiness.

And he doesn’t even need distinctive face so much because he definitionally only appears in costume. (┛◉Д◉)┛

summary: WHY IS EVERYONE SO MAD AT STEVE.
body:
WHY IS EVERYONE SO MAD AT STEVE.

He can’t be selfish and save Bucky or it’ll mess up the timeline and RUIN everything they did. All he can do is wear horrible disguises, avoid everything and call himself Lance or something.

tags: Mar-Vell and Talos had (in their opinion) justified reasons for what they did and so does Yon-Rogg
all of them including Carol are neither good nor evil that's not how this works kids
summary: Mar-Vell: drags Carol into a war she knew nothing about and had no involvement in without telling her what’s at stake and is...
body:
Mar-Vell: drags Carol into a war she knew nothing about and had no involvement in without telling her what’s at stake and is ready to sacrifice both of their lives in order to save the Skrulls when Carol still didn’t know what’s going on (and also must have done a lot of awful things when she was still on the side of the Kree)

some of you demons:

Talos: kidnaps Carol and would have killed her if he didn’t realize she was useful for him, he and and his buddy almost kill Fury, an innocent bystander with no ties to the Kree, twice, threatens to kill a small child

some of you demons:

Yon-Rogg: born in a military regime lead by a brainwashing A.I., influenced by the lies and propaganda that dominate his life, follows the orders of his superiors yet tries to avoid harming bystanders (warns the potentially dangerous “Torfans” several times without attacking them, only wants to kill Carol when it became unavoidable yet immediately lowers his gun when she tells him to wait), kills Mar-Vell who he thinks is a traitor who supports actual terrorists, takes Carol (who would have died anyway) with him, saves her life in the process (and perhaps potentially risks his own by doing so), tells her lies about her origin mostly because he is ordered to do it, treats Carol better than 99% of the people in her life, builds her up and boosts her ego, teaches her everything he knows, is there for her and supports her for six years, actually cares about her and values her as a person, even compliments her when she isn’t on his side anymore

some of you demons who never learnt the difference between a villain and an antagonist and are the personification of black-and-white thinking and double standards: Yon-Rogg is an abuser, the actual devil

summary: What Spider-Woman taught me about being a mom - WMQ Comics
title: What Spider-Woman taught me about being a mom - WMQ Comics
excerpt: In honor of Mother’s Day, WMQ Comics sought out guest contributors this week to write about positive portrayals of motherhood in comics. By CHRISTI EDDLEMAN, WMQ Comics guest contributor “This baby… has ruined my life.” The person in the panel staring back at me was all too familiar: an exhausted, unkempt woman in a T-shirt … Continue reading What Spider-Woman taught me about being a mom →
